Hi Martin,

Apologies for not including references to the relevant papers i=
n the first
place. :) The two most relevant journal articles (which describ=
e the same
EA and NN model but include some different tasks) are:

   - Evo=
lution of Cartesian Genetic Programs for Development of Learning
   Neural =
Architecture (
   http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/EVCO_a_00=
043 )
   - Where is the brain inside the brain? (
   http://www.springerlin=
k.com/content/v0925407k57v4115/abstract/ )

Through communication with Khan=
 I learnt that the initial network structure
(placement of neurons in geome=
tric space, etc) is the same throughout an
evolutionary run (but I think di=
ffers between runs), so the evolved genetic
programs that control the devel=
opment of the network probably rely on this
specific initial structure. How=
ever the development of the network
throughout its operational life is also=
 influenced by environmental input,
so it could be said to self-organise wi=
th respect to this. As discussed
previously on this list it's hard to draw =
many strong conclusions from this
work as it represents a radical departure=
 from anything that has gone
before and very little analysis was performed =
of the networks that were
evolved.

Thanks for the links to the various pap=
ers on self-organisation in natural
neural networks. This is probably nothi=
ng new, but it seems that
self-organisation is used in two ways (which I gu=
ess represent extremes of
a continuum):

   - environment-independent, wher=
e a structure (or the overall structure)
   forms largely due to interactio=
ns between the neural components alone, and
   is thus effectively specifie=
d by the genome, albeit very indirectly; and
   - environment-dependent, wh=
ere the structures that form are heavily
   influenced by environmental sig=
nals as well as the interactions between
   neural components (ie self-orga=
nising around the input).

So to answer the question "is there is an interp=
retation of CPPNs in
HyperNEAT that allows to conclude that self-organizati=
on must not be
explicitly modeled in these kinds of networks" (in your post=
 that you
linked to), my guess is that indirect encodings like HyperNEAT ca=
n replace
the environment-independent type of self-organisation, but that a=
s you move
towards environment-dependent self-organisation then abstraction=
s of
development like HyperNEAT can't play as much of a role (but perhaps c=
ould
still boost the process by providing some initial structure that is
fi=
ne-tuned by life-time self-organisation). So, my guess is that
abstractions=
 of development like HyperNEAT are useful, but can only take us
so far, and=
 that we will need to allow for life-time self-organisation
processes, too.=


Cheers,
Oliver
On 17 September 2012 18:58, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@gmail=
.com> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > Perhaps we could benefit
> > from explicitly stu=
dying it more in the context of neuroevolution (eg how
> > can we evolve ne=
ural networks that (must) use self-organisation
> mechanisms
> > to form th=
e required network structure or weight pattern; perhaps it
> > represents a=
 deceptive fitness landscape like (online) learning). Some of
> > Khan and =
Miller's work evolves neural networks that must self-organise
> due
> > to =
starting out with random structures at the start of every life-time.
> So
>=
 > it's great to have a paper that describes a neural network model that ca=
n
> > learn via an explicit self-organising process.
>
> Hi Oliver,
>
> can=
 you tell me, which paper you mean? I also think that self-organizing
> mec=
hanisms that are influenced by input from the environment are an
> importan=
t ingredient for the emergence of functions. I think the papers
> that I me=
ntioned in this post
>
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/58=
49
>
> point to interesting concepts (e.g. self-stabilizing mechanisms in
>=
 neurons) that should be further investigated in simulations.
>
> I also en=
joyed very much this paper "Evolution of declarative memory"
>
> http://www=
.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079
>
> which makes the point that the anatom=
y of the hippocampus (and therefore
> probably its function) is very well c=
onserved across mammals but depending
> on the neocortex to which it is att=
ached (e.g. in the fruit bat or
> chinchilla) the observable properties cha=
nge. So the behavioral function of
> a matured neural network should be dis=
tinguished from the properties of the
> network independent from its enviro=
nment.
>
> Best,
> Martin
>
>  
>

Hi Martin,<br><br>Apologies for not including references to the relevant pa=
pers in the first place. :) The two most relevant journal articles (which d=
escribe the same EA and NN model but include some different tasks) are:<br>=

<ul><li>Evolution of Cartesian Genetic Programs for Development of Learnin=
g Neural Architecture ( <a href=3D"http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/=
10.1162/EVCO_a_00043">http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/EVCO_=
a_00043</a> )</li>
<li>Where is the brain inside the brain? ( <a href=3D"ht=
tp://www.springerlink.com/content/v0925407k57v4115/abstract/">http://www.sp=
ringerlink.com/content/v0925407k57v4115/abstract/</a> )</li></ul><p>Through=
 communication with Khan I learnt that the initial network structure (place=
ment of neurons in geometric space, etc) is the same throughout an evolutio=
nary run (but I think differs between runs), so the evolved genetic program=
s that control the development of the network probably rely on this specifi=
c initial structure. However the development of the network throughout its =
operational life is also influenced by environmental input, so it could be =
said to self-organise with respect to this. As discussed previously on this=
 list it's hard to draw many strong conclusions from this work as it re=
presents a radical departure from anything that has gone before and very li=
ttle analysis was performed of the networks that were evolved.</p>
<p>Thank=
s for the links to the various papers on self-organisation in natural neura=
l networks. This is probably nothing new, but it seems that self-organisati=
on is used in two ways (which I guess represent extremes of a continuum): <=
br>
</p><ul><li>environment-independent, where a structure (or the overall =
structure) forms largely due to interactions between the neural components =
alone, and is thus effectively specified by the genome, albeit very indirec=
tly; and <br>
</li><li>environment-dependent, where the structures that for=
m are heavily influenced by environmental signals as well as the interactio=
ns between neural components (ie self-organising around the input).</li></u=
l><p>So to answer the question "is there is an interpretation of CPPNs=
 in HyperNEAT
that allows to conclude that self-organization must not be
ex=
plicitly modeled in these kinds of networks" (in your post that you li=
nked to), my guess is that indirect encodings like HyperNEAT can replace th=
e environment-independent type of self-organisation, but that as you move t=
owards environment-dependent  self-organisation then abstractions of develo=
pment like HyperNEAT can't play as much of a role (but perhaps could st=
ill boost the process by providing some initial structure that is fine-tune=
d by life-time self-organisation). So, my guess is that abstractions of dev=
elopment like HyperNEAT are useful, but can only take us so far, and that w=
e will need to allow for life-time self-organisation processes, too.</p>
<p=
>Cheers,<br>Oliver<br></p><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On 17 September 2012 1=

ckquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #c=
cc solid;padding-left:1ex">

n>

      <p></p><div class=3D"im"=
>> Perhaps we could benefit<br>
> from explicitly studying it more in=
 the context of neuroevolution (eg how<br>
> can we evolve neural networ=
ks that (must) use self-organisation mechanisms<br>
> to form the requir=
ed network structure or weight pattern; perhaps it<br>
> represents a de=
ceptive fitness landscape like (online) learning). Some of<br>
> Khan an=
d Miller's work evolves neural networks that must self-organise due<br>=

> to starting out with random structures at the start of every life-tim=
e. So<br>
> it's great to have a paper that describes a neural netwo=
rk model that can<br>
> learn via an explicit self-organising process.<b=
r>
<br></div>
Hi Oliver,<br>
<br>
can you tell me, which paper you mean? I =
also think that self-organizing mechanisms that are influenced by input fro=
m the environment are an important ingredient for the emergence of function=
s. I think the papers that I mentioned in this post<br>

<br>
<a href=3D"ht=
tp://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/5849" target=3D"_blank">http:=
//tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/5849</a><br>
<br>
point to inter=
esting concepts (e.g. self-stabilizing mechanisms in neurons) that should b=
e further investigated in simulations.<br>
<br>
I also enjoyed very much th=
is paper "Evolution of declarative memory"<br>
<br>
<a href=3D"ht=
tp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079" target=3D"_blank">http://www.ncb=
i.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079</a><br>
<br>
which makes the point that the a=
natomy of the hippocampus (and therefore probably its function) is very wel=
l conserved across mammals but depending on the neocortex to which it is at=
tached (e.g. in the fruit bat or chinchilla) the observable properties chan=
ge. So the behavioral function of a matured neural network should be distin=
guished from the properties of the network independent from its environment=
.<br>

<br>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
